description:
Bombilactobacillus bombi is a species of lactic acid bacteria that has been isolated from the digestive tract of bumblebees (Bombus spp.). It is a Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, facultatively anaerobic bacterium that belongs to the genus Bombilactobacillus.

The cells of B. bombi are typically rod-shaped and can form chains. They are capable of fermenting various carbohydrates, including glucose, fructose, and sucrose, to produce lactic acid as the primary end-product of their metabolism.

This species is believed to play a beneficial role in the gut microbiome of bumblebees, contributing to their overall health and potentially aiding in the digestion of nectar and pollen. The presence of B. bombi in the bumblebee gut may also help to inhibit the growth of potentially pathogenic microorganisms, thereby supporting the immune function of the host.

Further research is needed to fully understand the ecology, interactions, and potential applications of this lactic acid bacterium in the context of bumblebee biology and conservation.
